fields.title: Hyrax Tech Lead mentorship and training opportunity for 2025

content.value: The Samvera Community is seeking a volunteer
Hyrax Technical Lead for 2026
, and we’re excited to offer
mentorship and training for the role in 2025

. This is an excellent opportunity for a developer to gain valuable experience in community leadership, technical decision-making, and open-source contribution, all with the support of a skilled and collaborative team.

If you’re a developer working at an institution that has implemented Hyrax, this role could be a perfect fit for you. It’s ideal for someone who enjoys problem-solving, learning on the go, and contributing to the evolution of technical design and architecture.
Why Consider This Role?
Mentorship & Training
: Work directly with experienced leaders in the Hyrax community.
Leadership Experience
: Develop your skills in making impactful decisions for an active open-source project.
Tailored Expertise Welcome
: Whether your strengths lie in deployments, databases, Ruby programming, or another area, we can adapt the role to suit your expertise.
The Current Team

In 2025, Randall Floyd (Indiana University) will serve as Hyrax Technical Lead, with Indiana University generously supporting him at 40% time and Daniel Pierce contributing 25% of his time to Hyrax maintenance. Together with Nicholas Homenda (Tufts University), the team will provide strong leadership to ensure a smooth transition for the incoming 2026 Tech Lead.
However,
Indiana University will conclude its staffing for Hyrax technical leadership after 2025
, which is why we’re now looking for someone to step into the role for 2026.
Your Opportunity as a “Tech Lead in Training”
To make the transition manageable, we’re offering a
Hyrax Tech Lead mentorship opportunity in 2025
. This role allows you to:

Commit a portion of your time to Hyrax maintenance. The specifics can be arranged with your institution based on your local development schedule, but ideally this would be a percentage of your time during the Maintenance Working Group sprints every two weeks.
Gain hands-on leadership experience under the guidance of Randall and Daniel.
Receive a
free seat
in any developer training offered by the Samvera Community in 2025.

This is your chance to step into an important leadership position with the full backing of the Hyrax Maintenance Working Group and the Hyrax Interest Group, who will support you by sharing responsibilities.
How to Get Involved
If you’re interested in becoming the
Hyrax Tech Lead in Training
please fill out this form by
February 21, 2025
Have questions? Feel free to reach out to me or join us at the
Hyrax Interest Group call on February 12th
to learn more about the role.
Thank you for considering this opportunity to shape the future of Hyrax while growing your skills and impact in the Samvera Community.

fields.title: The Year in Review and a big thank you

content.value: Thank you to everyone in the Samvera Community for your incredible commitment to building and sustaining our work throughout the year. Your activities -- sharing your knowledge in interest groups, leading community initiatives, participating in community sprints, and attending community events - are what keeps this community so vibrant and welcoming. I am truly excited and grateful to help facilitate it all.
Here is a "Year in Review" infographic
(PDF) sharing some of what we accomplished this year. Please feel free to share this with anyone else who should know that your participation is valuable and gets results. You can also
watch the State of Samvera overview and end of year updates from Samvera technologies on YouTube

.

Wishing you a joyful holiday season, a well-earned break, and a new year filled with even more collaboration and mutual support!
Heather Greer Klein, Community Manager

fields.title: Hyku for Consortia transitions from pilot phase to full production

content.value: The Partnership for Academic Library Collaboration and Innovation (PALCI) and the Private Academic Library Network of Indiana (PALNI) are proud to announce the successful transition of Hyku for Consortia from pilot phase to full production—now serving 40 libraries across four prominent partners in the
Hyku Commons
: PALCI, PALNI, the Boston Library Consortium (BLC), and the Virtual Library of Virginia (VIVA).

This milestone marks a significant achievement for the project, as Hyku for Consortia moves beyond initial testing to provide stable, production-level service supported by a robust, community-driven infrastructure. Additionally, collaborators recently received
another round of funding from the Institute of Museum and Library Services
to enhance and sustain the Hyku open-source community.

“The transition to production includes rigorous testing of our business model to ensure that Hyku can sustainably meet the needs of consortial libraries,” says Amanda Hurford, PALNI Scholarly Communications Director. “As we continue to refine and adjust this model, our focus remains on creating an open-source, adaptable repository platform that scales efficiently across institutions. Ongoing funding from the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) is helping fuel this process, ensuring we have the resources to both sustain and enhance Hyku for long-term success.”
Read more about this exciting development on the Hyku for Consortia website.
